details: Phone interview was a fairly straightforward technical question and mainly just talking about the company and your experience. The next step is a technical test administered by a third party company that has you install software so the proctors can take control of your computer and manually close applications. While you test they watch you through a webcam and tell you you can't leave until you're done with the test.…  They also have you scan the area you're in with you're camera before you begin. They had some coding questions as well as asking you to learn an unfamiliar language and answer questions about it.
questions: Questions about how an unfamiliar language works after it is introduced to you.

details: Got a recruitment email from my profile on an internship website, chatted with an HR rep, asked to put in an application. Within a few days, had a phone interview and asked to complete a skills test, which was fairly easy. Basic string manipulation. Waited 3 weeks, but eventually got called for an on-site interview. Amazing place, extremely relaxed atmosphere. The day of interviews was a breeze. Waiting to hear…  back.
questions: Phone interview- high level ADTsCode assessment- string manipulationOn site- describe a project, database questions

details: There are stage which are listed on their site.Stages:    1. Phone Interview    2. Assessment    3. Final InterviewThe phone interview starts easy enough. Simple questions about how you found the company what what you know of the company. After that, you will be asked a simple logic question related to programming. Once you answer you are done and he'll tell you if you made it to the next step. The phone call was about…  30 mins.The next stage is the assessment. This can be done online from your computer or you can go to a location to be proctored. If you take it on your computer, you will need to use a proctoring program. The program captures your screen. They require you to have a webcam and microphone as well. If you cannot do this like me, they set you up with a proctoring location and you will take the test there on a computer. The assessment has 2 phases, a multiple choice section which is logic questions and a section that requires you to write code to solve 4 different problems. The code can be written in C/C++, Java, Python, and some other languages. There is a list to choose from. The test will take about 2-3 hours.I have started the final interview yet.
questions: How did you learn about us?
Do you know what our company does?

details: Contact the recruiter during a campus job fair. Got an invitation email for online assessment. The Online assessment is followed by onsite. Got an offer within a week of onsite.
questions: The first round is just an online assessment. Easy match question and several programming questions about permutations stuff. Onsite is non-technical. Mostly talk about previous projects and high level design questions.

details: Had phone call with a software developer who just asked behavioral type questions. Was then given an online test that was mainly coding. After that was given an onsite interview where I was asked a couple of more technical questions, and an interview with the HR. Despite making it to the onsite, I was not made an offer. But the campus is really amazing though.
questions: Tell me about a software project you have worked on.

details: They reached out to me to apply online. Once I filled out the form, they emailed me asking for my availability for an initial phone interview. They also asked, at this step, that I complete a personality assessment and a skills assessment (one more focused on my ability to learn the basics to a coding language and another that was more like the yearly standardized assessments from primary and secondary…  school). I could complete these before the phone interview or shortly thereafter. A week later, they called about my salary expectations and then asked me to fill out another online form concerning my availability to go to their campus to interview.The on site interview was pretty relaxed. Mine started with an introduction to their product, followed by an overview of the position and a short group activity where we were asked how we would go about testing the quality of a randomly selected object. After that, there was a case interview where I read over some information and then was asked about how I would respond and prioritize my time; there were also follow up questions. That was followed by an interview with an HR representative (mostly your standard why Epic, what's an area of improvement you have, etc). I had lunch with two other candidates and an Epic employee; he was wonderful and even walked us back from lunch on a different routeoso we could see more of the campus. My day ended with a very short tour of the campus and a trip down the indoor slide.
questions: If you could pick the themes for three new buildings on the company campus, which three would you choose and why?

details: They came to my college, and I applied after they talked to us there. The interview was from a real software developer and we talked about my experience of programming and doing CS at college. After that I scheduled to do an online programming assessment which was pretty challenging but I can't say more than that. They hire like ~200 interns so they really assess you on how fast and…  accurate you are at this programming challenge.
questions: What was one of the hardest parts of a program that you worked on and how did you traverse it?

details: I applied through a recruiter, waited 2 whole months. Gave them a call to find out that they "moved forward with other candidates." I think a company should have at least some dignity to contact the candidates that didn't make the interview process.

First there was a phone call with a software dev to discuss my resume and go into detail about a project I worked on - he asked some pretty in depth questions. After that was the three hour online proctored exam which was more annoying than difficult. Finally they flew me out to Madison for a day of interviews which were very relaxed;
questions: Questions about a project I worked on, oo design questions, string manipulation for the coding exam

details: There's a simple interview process with a phone interview, a technical exam, and finally an onsite interview. The phone interview isn't really technical, just a test to see if you're a functional human being. The technical exam is rather on the long side (unlimited time / 2-3 hours). They ask you a bunch of mc questions on a programming language they make up followed by 4 programming questions. Still waiting…  on reply.
questions: Describe your previous projects, what were some challenges, what did you like

details: I initially applied online at a college career fair. I got an e-mail about a week later about setting up a phone interview, during which I spoke with a software developer about why I was interested in the company, as well as a small semi-technical piece to see gauge my problem solving abilities. This was followed by an online assessment that involved both a logic SAT-like portion, and a technical…  portion consisting of 4 questions. You can code in any language you're comfortable with. It took me about 3 hours to finish! About a month later, I got an invite to interview with them on-site. They fly you over, and you get to tour the company buildings (which look really cool!), meet some other applicants/employee, get a company overview, and do a problem-solving interview. You're also expected to be prepared to talk about a project you worked on. Still waiting to hear back!
questions: Talk about a project you worked on.

details: I was contacted the same day I submitted my application for a phone interview. That was about 30 minutes to talk about my resume with a software developer. Then I had a 3-hour technical assessment of 4 basic algorithm questions and a section about learning a new programming language. I was then flown on-site for a 5-hour day on their campus, including a tour, lunch, and three interviews - explaining…  a project I have done, a case study, and HR.
questions: Knowledge of heaps, arrays, and string manipulation are necessary

details: I first applied through my school's career network. Got an initial call phone screen where the engineer asked me about my background and some of my projects. Then I got an online coding test where they used a third party proctor. The coding test is fairly simple, recursion and for loops. Then I got invited to their onsite in Madison, WI. During the onsite interview they ask you to tell…  them about a project you did, also they ask you a design question.
questions: Tell me about a project you did.Go through a design problem with an engineer.

details: First step is an initial phone screening that is not technical. They ask you about your previous projects and tell you about the company as well as allow you to ask any questions. After that is an online assessment that isn't timed.
questions: What did you learn from your project? What did you find difficult?

details: Applied on the website. Was emailed about 2 days later to schedule a phone interview to be done about 2 days later. The phone interview is exactly what they said it would be like on their site; talk about a project and asked me two technical questions. One I had no idea about but the interviewer was very nice about it and asked me another one. Asked me what I…  knew about the company, why I wanted to be a software developer, and what I knew about Madison and if I had any questions for him. At the end of the interview he asked me if I wanted to schedule the assessment and that I would be receiving an email soon to set it up. About 5 days later I took the assessment. The technical part was not too difficult, but some of the questions I was pretty clueless about. The programming part was 4 questions and got progressively harder. The first two questions were not too difficult, but the last question I barely even knew where to start because I hadn't used python in a while.
questions: During phone interview: If you had a string of words, how would you show the string in reverse?

details: Dropped a resume off on Epic's page on my college's career website. I received an email two days later encouraging me to apply online. About a week later, I had a phone interview with a developer. Some behavioral questions, some basic technical questions, not too bad for a phone interview. After that was the online test. This was actually pretty brutal due to how long it was (starting the exam…  after midnight didn't help). If you pass the phone interview and the test, you get invited onsite. I think at this point, as a developer, as long as your top reference is pretty good and you don't screw up your onsite interviews (which aren't hard), you're in pretty good shape. I received an offer 2.5 weeks after the onsite
questions: In depth programming questions

details: Guys!!! Don't bother applying here if you are older than 27.They just reject you. Age discrimination sucks!! I never believed when my friend told about it but only after experiencing the same
questions: what is your work experience..why epic blah blah

details: Starts out with an online application with behavioral short answer questions. Then a 30 minute phone call with a developer. Mostly behavioral and one quick technical question. Then an online proctored technical test. Different math/problem solving tests then I think 3 technical coding questions. Strings, DP, etc. If that goes well, they fly you up. This is pretty much for you to feel out the company. You see a product…  demo, talk with engineers, etc. The only interview parts are describing in detail a project you've worked on and then a behavioral with HR.
questions: General algorithms questions

details: I applied through their site after talking to them at a career fair. First step was a short phone interview with a developer at epic. The interview consisted mostly of questions about my background and interests, as well as things about what it was like working at epic. Nothing that technical. After this I was set up with a skills assessment test to take. It was essentially an online coding…  test. I don't exactly remember the questions asked, but I remember them being somewhat difficult.
questions: Name a time when you had issues with a partner or partners(s) a group and how did you handle it?

details: There was an easy resume/experience based phone interview, then the online assessment with ProctorU which took me about 3.5 hours, and then finally an onsite interview. Everything was pretty much what others have reported - tedious online assessment that was mostly coding, but the onsite interview was actually awesome. They flew me in on short notice and put me up in a very nice lakeside hotel with a bunch of…  other candidates. A full time employee took a small group of us out to a really nice dinner and there was breakfast in the morning at the hotel and once you arrive at the campus. The day of interviews was about half them giving you info about what it's like to work there and half was relaxed interviews. It is very well organized and it all went by very quickly, so make sure that you have prepared yourself for everything before it starts since you won't have any time between interviews. The campus is even cooler than I expected it to be - be sure to walk around on your own if you have time after your interview.
questions: They were exactly what everyone else said they would be. Case study, weaknesses, where do you see yourself in 5 years, etc.

details: Epic's hiring process primarily consists of three parts: (1) a nontechnical phone interview, in which you discuss previous development experience, education, motivation for pursuing a job at Epic; (2) an online skills assessment, which comprises a short technical assessment (learning a new programming language) and a 4-question programming assessment (which took my a little over 2 hours); and (3) an onsite visit in Verona, WI.
questions: The online programming assessment covered many of the typical technical interview questions, including questions about data structures, string manipulation, dynamic programming, and recursion. The onsite interviews consisted of a 30 minute discussion of a previous project and a 1-on-1 software design interview, both with current software developers.

details: I was given a phone interview and then a series of online exams meant to review my skills for the job I was applying for. Overall, the phone interview was a little hard to understand as the person who interviewed me had a heavy accent which would have been easier to comprehend had it been in person and not over the phone. The test was slightly difficult but straight forward.
questions: Why do you want to work at Epic?

details: After submitting the application Online, I was contacted by email to set up a phone interview which took place 2 days after I received the email. The phone interview was only 30 minutes and mostly went over my resume, and any projects I have done in the past. Following the phone interview, I scheduled a Skills Assessment within the next few days. The skills assessment was straight forward. Learn a…  new coding language and answer some question relating to it. Following that was four coding questions. After the skills assessment, I was contacted 4 weeks later with the final result.
questions: Write a function that when given two words, shows every step it takes to turn the first word into the second word by only switching two letters that are touching. For example MUG turning into GUM:MUGMGUGMUGUM

details: Applied online and got an e-mail to schedule a phone interview after 2 business days. Phone interview was about behavioral questions, like all others...nothing difficult. After the phone interview, you have to schedule an online technical assessment monitoring by ProctorU. This was rather painful because it lasted 3 hours. The technical assessment had 2 parts. In the first part, you have learned a weird new programming language and answer 20…  multiple choice question. It was quite tricky because it's very different from the language you're used to. The more you're used to a language, the more likely you're going to make some careless mistake. The second part consists of 4 programming assignment, which was in somewhat okay difficulty. You can do it in any language you wish. Non-CS major can even do it in pseudocode. It was like taking a test. You can't compile your code so you don't whether it works and you can search for library and function syntax so you have to be good at a language. After that, they will fly you to an on-site interview. You talk about your project, hearing them brag about Epic, go through a case study (OOP design), and have lunch.
questions: Find an occurrence of a word in a NxN matrix and print it. It can be horizontal, vertical or diagnal.

details: There was an initial phone screen with a developer who asked basic questions (how'd you learn about Epic? Why are you interested in the position? Are you willing to relocate to Madison? Etc...) nothing too probing/demanding and no technical questions whatsoever.After that, there was a programming skills test where you could use whatever language you wanted, even pseudocode. The questions themselves were very simple, so I'm not sure what exactly…  they were hoping to learn from it.Finally I was flown in onsite and treated lavishly, put up in a really nice hotel and given 2 fancy dinners in Madison (one the night of arrival and one the night after the interview), one with a technical problem solver and another with a developer. The interview day itself didn't really feel like too much of an interview for me. I basically just got to talk to a bunch of different developers, had a nice free lunch, and got a tour of the huge/nerdy campus. The only real interview questions I got were a few behavior ones from the HR person at the end, and even those just seemed like part of a conversation more than anything else.
questions: What would one of my recommenders say is one of my weaknesses?

details: There are three steps to the interview process (for interns, at least):1) Basic phone interview. This is easy, a formality almost. They just chat, ask about your major, a project you've worked out, etc. Nothing to worry about.2) Exam. This is the hardest part. It's a two part exam electronically proctored exam, one containing a general 20 question exam measuring learning aptitude. All epic applicants have to take this, regardless…  of position. They give you a dummy (weird) programming language and teach it to you, and then have you answer questions about it as you go. The second part, for programming applicants only, is just 4 interview-style programming questions that you type up in the language of your choice. This part required more mental stamina for me, so I would do this first and the other second, as you get to choose which to take first. I did not enjoy this part. This is also the part where most applicants seem to be weeded out.3) On-site interview. This part was great. They fly you out to Madison, put you in a hotel for the night, have an employee take you to dinner and ask all the questions you want. The next day is the actual interview day where they take you on a tour around campus, have a session where they show you around their software, have you meet individually with a former intern, and feed you lunch. Very, very impressive, engaging campus. Lots of opportunities to ask questions. There are two interviews, one with an engineer who will discuss one of the projects you've done for a half hour or so, and then one with an HR representative who asks typically behavioral questions. Most people on glassdoor say the on-site interview is easy and that you're basically guaranteed the position if you make it there, but I was not given an offer, so either that's not true or I did something wrong that I can't identify.
questions: Tell me about a project you've worked on (they then will try to find all the flaws in it)

details: Pretty interesting interview process. I talked to them first at a career fair, but that did not seem too important as they just had me apply online. Then they scheduled a phone interview, which is less of an interview than a personality screening. It was very conversational, basically describing life at Epic. They did ask one programming question, but it was pretty simple. Next, I took an assessment online through…  this weird service called ProctorU. This was pretty strange - they basically have control of your computer and watch you through your webcam while you take the test. It had two parts: for the first, they make up a language and you have to answer multiple choice questions about it. The second part was more difficult. In that, you had to answer a couple of programming questions in any language you choose. Unfortunately, I did not pass the test. It was a positive experience overall, though.
questions: Why Epic?

details: Online application very quickly translated to a half-hour discussion with a nice software developer. Then I was sent a ~3 hour coding exam (!) through a proctor website where someone watches you, installs software on your computer, etc. If this is how they treat their prospective employees, why would I want to work there?
questions: Know string manipulation in Java, C, C++

details: HR is fast in contacting you back, it only took them 3 days after I applied. They wanted to schedule a phone interview for that week.The brief phone interview wasn't brief at all.... I thought it was just supposed to be behavioral or an introduction to their company but turned out to be a little bit more technical. The person asked me to describe a CS project then asked me…  questions about it. Then based off of those project asked me how I could improve on it or what other alternative algorithms or methods I could've used.I'm about to take the skills assessment in a couple of days.
questions: Asked me about my recent cs project then tried to make me explain about what it does and what algorithms it uses. Then offered different scenarios and algorithms to see if I could think logically and know what I was talking about.

details: Applied online and was later contacted to set up a phone interview. A current developer called me and asked basic questions, such as describe a project you've created. No specific technical questions were asked over the phone. Most of it was him telling me about EPIC.
questions: Tell me about a project you've completed.

details: Had a phone interview which lasted for 15 to 20 minutes. Questions were simple and straight forward based on my resume. Got a call after a week that i passed and later scheduled for a skills test. Skills test is not that difficult but it will test our thought process and logic.
questions: Skills test is based on logical and some programming questions. Unfortunately couldn't crack the test.

details: The interview consists of a short phone interview (something like 20 minutes to 45 minutes), online assessment test and an onsite interview. In general, they contact a person after he applies online after 1 week or so. However, sometimes, it may take longer. In general , you will contacted by the HR department of the company which will handle the interview process.
questions: Just normal questions including your name, and other stuff. In general, they do not ask a technical question over the phone. But they may ask about some details about the resume. They also ask you how you got to know the company.

details: They start with a 15 minute informal call to gauge interest in the company. Then you take an online assessment. This part is technical and can take about 1-3 hours. It is not like other technical interviews where someone from the company calls you to ask you questions; it's pretty much a test that you do on your own. There were math, logic, and programming sections. After that they fly…  you on site for a behavioral interview (there are no technical interviews on site!).
questions: Standard programming questions; math questions were mainly arithmetic.

details: After a brief phone interview (in which they asked one technical question), I had a technical interview set up through Proctor U for a long coding exam. It must have changed from the past, because the software portion was quite considerable, and had two portions. One about a new language, and one that was a common coding procedure.
questions: To utilize a new made-up language and do basic functions like concatenation a,d such

details: When you apply, HR will call you and do a phone interview. The standard questions are asked. What kinds of projects have you worked on? Have you ever been in a situation where you had to overcome a challenge?If you make it through the phone screening, they then ask you take an online proctored (through a webcam) programming skill assessment. The assessment was quite difficult, but to be expected for…  such a developer driven company.If you do well on the programming skills assessment, then Epic will fly you out to their main campus in Madison, WI for a final interview. The final interview will consist of a programming case-study, a presentation of a previous project of your choice, and an HR behavioral meeting.
questions: What do you expect to make while working here?

details: I applied for the summer Software Developer internship. The first stage was a phone interview, which was very simple. Basic questions about my resume, and then I was asked about a project I've completed, and what I might change about it. About ten minuted after I received a link to complete an online skills assessment, which consisted of two parts. The first was answer 20 multiple choice questions about a…  language they made up. These were pretty basic questions and were timed. The second part was four coding questions. Untimed, but they take into account how long it took you and your accuracy. The four questions really weren't too crazy as long as you've taken some some programming courses or are self-taught and somewhat experienced. I'm waiting to hear back. They said it would take a couple weeks to get back to me, and if I did well, I will be invited to an in-person interview. Best of luck!
questions: What project have you worked on? Why Epic?

details: Had a phone screen, then got called in for an on-site. The phone interview was straightforward, and just asked about my projects and work experience. The on-site was mostly a tour of the campus, and also a presentation of one of my projects.
questions: What would you improve about your project?

details: First you have a phone interview where someone will ask you about your resume, interests, whether you are willing to relocateStrange service called proctorU which basically monitors your every movement during the test. Not the most comforting test environment.Didnt make it to the onsite interview, but I imagine that the questions are more knowledge based than they were on the test.
questions: They ask a lot of string manipulation questions. CS majors have to write code in Java or C/C++. Other majors can use VB, Python, or even pseudocode.

details: 1 Phone interview where you cover your resume and possibly a technical question. This is followed by the proctored online assessment. Expect to learn a new language in this and to use a language you know to solve 4 programming problems.If you get past the first two stages they invite you on site (paid for, stay at hilton and eat good food).The onsite is 3 interviews. One technical where they…  present you with a business problem you must help solve, a section where you present on a project you have done, and finally an HR interview.All in all the Epic interview is above average in difficulty, but of course the job is a good one with a well above average salary.
questions: What technical solutions can we provide to keep physicians and patients up to date on their vaccinations. Design the system

details: Talked to someone on the phone, then had an online technical interview, then finally visited the campus for some more interviews. Kind of a lengthy process, but none of the questions were too difficult.
questions: Pretty standard software interview questions, study up on dynamic programming. None of the questions were too difficult.

details: first they emailed to set up a phone interview, then they had you do the phone interview and then if you pass that you take a long exam that was pretty tough. it took me about 2 hours to finish (though i BSed like 2 of the 6 questions). the multiple choice part wasn't bad though
questions: why do you want to work for us

details: Met at campus career fair, quickly emailed to schedule a phone interview. Phone interview was a 30 minute conversation about personal projects and the company in general. Scheduled an online skills assessment, which had 4 programming questions and a section where you learned a programming language. (You can use pseudo code or any language you want in the programming questions). After that I was invited onsite, which was mostly checking…  to make sure it would be a good fit on both ends. A short interview highlighting personal projects and problem solving techniques, and an HR interview about why I wanted to be there, and a lot of information on the campus and culture. Pretty quick to respond to everything, just took a while because of all the steps.
questions: What problems did you come across while making personal projects? Any creative solutions to particular problems?

details: The phone interview went pretty good. Just talking with my background and what they are doing right now. At the online coding test, I failed it. The question is pretty simple. 3 questions totally. But I haven't prepare for it at that time.
questions: regular expression matching questions. You need to run the code

details: A phone interview regarding behavior questions, then asked you to do an online assessment. The online assessment consists 4 part, among which the 4 coding questions are the most challenging. However, they don't seem to grade the assessment by accuracy. The onsite contains an behavior part and an technical part which asks you to explain one of your project explicitly. It is actually like a kind of tour, introducing themselves…  to you and see if you fit their culture.
questions: why epic, what weakness do you think you have

details: telephone and next written testtelephone interview was just the HR where in employee will be telling you about epicwritten- there are 4 sections out of which first one is speed and accuracy and this section decides the rest of the test. so please be more cautious with that

Applied at my university's career fair. I received an email to set up a phone interview. The phone interview was very relaxed and the engineer was easy to talk to. Basically just asked why I want to work at Epic and about projects I've worked on professionally, but none of the big projects I've done on the side.Within 15 minutes of the phone interview I received an email to take…  their programming assessment.I took the test the next day as there was no way to study for it. They used an online proctor program with webcam / microphone monitoring. In the first section they teach you about a new language and test you on it. This part can be tricky because their tutorial is not very specific and some of the questions were very much debatable. Unfortunately you don't get that opportunity, so pick wisely.The next part of the test took me a little over 2 hours. It was 4 programming questions in a row and you are not allowed to use the bathroom (or do anything for that matter) because these questions are all in one section. Definitely keep that in mind when moving on with this section, as it made it very hard for me to focus towards the end and I could've done better if it weren't for this limitation. Nevertheless, I know I did fine in this section, but probably not as well as they wanted.Though I did get rejected, I gave this interview experience a thumbs down because:1) Even companies like Google understand that Java APIs and syntactical questions are online and it is impractical to test someone on how well they know a specific API. Epic seems to be especially different here, but that is my opinion.2) The proctor set up was a little overboard.3) Though I've been employed in development for years, I'm disappointed that the projects I've done in my free time meant little to nothing to them, though many of them were on my resume, I put a lot of time into them, they are online, and they did not try them out (I checked!). This is an application for an internship, not a full-time position. Let's be realistic here. Some of the most dedicated students are staying are spending their weekend nights and playing with technologies and building projects that are meaningful to them. I feel that you can learn a lot about a person from that.I emailed them for feedback to improve on myself but have yet to receive a response.If Epic is the only place you want to work my advice is to only on algorithms and data structures.
questions: Why Epic?
Tell me about a project you've worked on.
Spiral array question, assumedly using a 2D array.

details: Once you have submitted an online application, an initial phone interview will be scheduled with a current software engineer. Then, an online assessment will be schedule for you within the next week. Once you have completed the assessment, you will have a chance to proceed to an onsite interview. If everything goes well, you will receive an offer.
questions: What was your favorite project? What kind of technology did you use?

details: I met them at a job fair, gave them my resume, had a phone interview a week or so later, then took an online test I had to sign an NDA for. Sort of a weirdly sexist vibe from one of the 2 guys at the job fair but otherwise everyone was pleasant and friendly. Pretty laid back group of people overall, casual dress and manner.
questions: Why are you interested in working for Epic

details: I received an email about applying to them. The application was fairly easy, and then I received an email about having a quick 30 minute phone interview. This was very behavioral and not much more than a resume overlook and opportunity for you to ask about Epic. Then the technical assessment came. I applied for an internship the year before and had the 4 part exam that everyone else has…  mentioned. This was not that! It was just 4 coding questions that seemed to be quite a bit harder than the internship one. I was expecting 3 more sections after but there was just the 1.
questions: What gives you the interest to be a software developer at Epic?

details: The company came to a campus career fair and encouraged to apply online. After applying online, they asked for a phone interview. The phone interview was easy. Then came the online assessment. I had to get a proctor to watch that the online assessment was done without cheating. The assessment comprised of three parts. I didn't get after the assessment part.
questions: Reversing a linked list.

details: There are three levels of hiring:1. Phone call interview: They ask some general questions about work you have done and have you describe a project that you have worked on.2. Online Assessment: Consisted of 4 programming problems. You should study up on Java or C before taking because the problems are pretty complex. Search online for "practice programming problems" to practice. I would practice a lot if you haven't done…  competitive programming.3. On-Side interview: This actually consists of a tour, free lunch, hotel stay if out of town, and talking with many different developers. There were two semi-formal interviews. One where you described in depth a project you have worked on, the other where you are given a programming problem and asked to discuss it. You meet with your HR rep at the end and ask some simple questions.I am waiting for response. They said it should only take a week.
questions: 1. About your references, what would your references say about you?2. How did you hear about Epic?3. What is something about you that many people don't know?

details: During a career fair, I went to Epic's booth and talked to both people there. I asked questions about Epic, told them what I knew and said a little about myself. I filled out their online application through one of their tablets and gave my resume to the Software Developer there. I received an email to submit my resume online later that day. A couple days later I received an…  email to schedule a phone interview. After the phone interview, I received an email to take their online assessment.
questions: Why Epic?

details: I applied online. There was a behavioral screen followed by a coding challenge consisting of two halves. The coding challenge lasted 3 1/2 hours long. You were watched by an online proctor through your webcam for its entirety, pretty creepy to be honest. Also, they take control of your computer and disable all external ports.The first half's objective was to learn a fake programming language and answer questions at the…  end of each section. I might be stupid but I honestly thought the documentation and how the language was constructed was very poor leaving me confused half of the time.The second half consisted of four standard programming languages. The text editor is just a plain HTML text box. No documentation is allowed. The proctors didn't let me use the restroom either.
questions: Given a string of digits i.e "14982". Find all substrings of digits, like "149" and "1". Calculate the product between the digits (so for "149" it's 36). Return whether all such products of substrings is unique or not.

details: At first, it's phone interview. Then online assessment. Finally it's on site interview. Phone interview will ask you about your academic projects, and ask you how you know about Epic. Online assessment will ask you to log in to ProctorU and ask you to type the codes on web-based text editor. You cannot use anything else. Final interview will ask you to prepare one of your academic projects to give…  interviewer a 20 mins presentation. Then there will be a case study to talk about how you solve a problem when you meet one. Finally you will meet HR again and this part is very important. Please keep a good relationship with HR!
questions: Online assessment: Jumpers, additive number, Gibberize String, Seed Sum.

details: The interview process is three phases:The first phase starts with a phone screening if you pass it you will go to the next phase.The second phase is a technical assessment. This phase has two parts the first one is to learn a new language and answer questions about it (it was easy). The second one was 4 algorithm questions two of them are normal you need to use collections and…  for loop to solve them, and for me I found the last two questions difficult specially because you can't use and IDE or the Internet, the third question needs a good preparation for recursive method, for the fourth question you have to practice the multidimensional array.The third part will be onsite interview which I didn't get it :)Which you the best.
questions: The third question was to generate all possible values for a string (for example if you have 'mother' sent as a string generate all possible strings you can have with the letters m, o, t, h, e, r like 'mthero', 'omther', 'therom', .....)

details: Applied online. Got an email about a week later saying i would be granted an interview. First interview is over the phone. They mostly ask behavioral questions and about past experience. Next is an online test, takes about 3 hours, and is where they weed most people out. If you do well, they fly you out to madison and show you around campus. You also have two low stress interviews…  there, one about a past project with a developer, and another with HR
questions: John went to a store and asked how much a certain item costs. The clerk said 1 dollar. John said "Okay, I'll have 600." The clerk said, okay your total bill is 3 dollars. What did John Buy?

details: Pretty much like the others. I was contacted by a recruiter, had a phone interview, then did the test at Proctor U. I found the Proctor U test extremely difficult and time consuming.After that Epic flew me to Madison on Sunday, and out on Tuesday. I had a personality test to fill out.I had three interviews on Monday: A HR interview, an project demonstration interview, and a problem solving interview.I…  performed well on the HR and problem solving interviews. I think I fell a bit short on the project demonstration interview. I spent most of my time discussing parts of the project I have been unable to solve. I believe I highlighted my shortcomings rather than emphasize my strengths in this interview.Also, Epic seemed very interested in my college transcripts. Unfortunately, I am a below-average student, so I don't think this helped me much.Ultimately HR called me and said they had to pick other candidates, but that it was nice meeting me.
questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

details: There are three rounds of the interview. 1) The first round is a phone interview. Just go through the resume and answer some behavior questions. 2) After a week, I was asked to do an online assessment which has two parts. Learn a new language and solve four coding problems. 3) A month later, I had the final onsite round, I was asked to do a presentation about one of…  my academic projects, followed with a case study, finally I had a talk with the HR.
questions: Why software developer? and 5 years plan.

details: I applied online through EPIC website.I got an email in a week asking me to schedule for phone interview.Phone interview was a HR round. They explained about the company.What technologies they use.I was asked questions from my resume.How I came to know about EPIC and how did I apply.And Why EPIC?I was asked to explain briefly two of my projects from resume.I explained in 10 minutes.After the phone Interview, I…  got an email for the next steps.Would be giving soon.
questions: I was asked questions from my resume.How I came to know about EPIC and how did I apply.I was asked to explain briefly two of my projects from resume.

details: I applied online.Got a phone interview schedule. The phone interview was 30 minutes asking about your resume, background and status.If they like you, you will get a skill assessment test. It is very important step. You can find sample questions online. You need about a week to get a good score on that test.Skill assessment for me had two parts. First, Learning a new language. Second, 4 programming questions. You…  need to know the language as well as the algorithm.If you do good at skill assessment, you will get a site interview to meet them in person at Wisconsin.I am still waiting for the result.
questions: Phone interview:Mostly about your background, work experience and overall status.Programming questions;String permutation. String combination, hashmap and collections.

details: I applied by sending my resume after seeing the job post on my school's website. Less than a week later I got an email from a recruiter asking me to schedule a phone interview and to pick a time to take the ProctorU test... The phone interview was pretty basic with a lot questions like: what is your favorite project? What challenges did you encounter? How did you deal with…  them? You should be ready to discuss everything on your resume and you should have some good stories to tell about your projects... Took the ProctorU test a few days later. The test was divided in two parts. The first part covered questions, about 20 of them, of a made-up language. Some were really easy, others required more thinking; all in all don't necessarily go with your fits instinct. The second part had 4 programming questions where pseudocode could be used. In hindsight the programming questions were quite doable and exactly like the questions posted for Epic interviews here, on career cup and all other forums. You have to be very comfortable with arrays and know your data structures... The ProctorU test is timed, I think the longest you can stay and take it is 4 hours.
questions: Why do you want to work for Epic?

details: I have done with the phone interview in which they have asked about my projects from resume. I have scheduled for assessment test which is on 9th july. In that, they said there will be math, coding and some new programming language with questions on that.
questions: Where do you want to see you in the next 5 to 10 years?

details: Got a call for a phone interview. You get to talk with a Software Developer, who asks you questions about your background and experience. You also get a brief overview of the company and the position.After the phone screen, there was an online assessment test on ProctorU. It had 2 sections. In the first section, they introduce a new programming language to you and you have to answer questions based…  on that. They check, how fast you grasp new concepts in this section. And, in the second section you have to solve 4 out of the book programming problems.
questions: 1. Why do you want to work for Epic ?2. Explain any one of your project.3. Where do you see yourself in five years ?

details: I applied for it online. Total 4 rounds. 1st round is phone ! asked me ..y epic ? where do u want to see u in the next 5 yrs ? 2nd round is
questions: y epic ?

details: Just as most others here have described, the interview was pretty straight forward and focused on my background in school. He asked me to talk about several of the projects I've worked on, and the types of programming languages I'm most comfortable with, etc. He did ask a specific question about one of my past projects, regarding how I would adapt a single player trivia game to work over a…  network with multiple players.
questions: Why do you want to be a software developer?
Where do you see yourself in the next 5 years?

details: Was contacted by a recruiter at Epic. Then received a phone interview call which lasted for 40 mins approximately. Then got an email from recruiter to schedule an online assessment. Then got an onsite interview invitation. Waiting for results.
questions: Why CS ?

details: there was a telephone interview and they asked me basic questions in my resume. I was told by them to go for skills assessment test and i am taking it on august 1st
questions: What are your strengths

details: Cool interview process, once you get an onsite interview call, usually they will hire you. Typically takes around 1 month to complete the whole process. It begins with a phone interview, then usually followed by a 3-4 hour technical assessment, and then followed by onsite call.
questions: How do you see yourself after 5 years?

details: First off , an introductory phone call from an Epic Software Developer whom provides basic debriefing of what the job entails. One week later, you will be asked to take an online proctored exam consisting of 4 programming questions in a language of your choice. If all goes well, then they will contact you for an onsite interview.
questions: Count the number of character occurrences in a given String.

details: I applied online, then heard back from the hr soon and set up a phone interview. The interviewer was a senior engineer in Epic. Firstly she ask me to introduce a most recently project and then asked some related questions with it. Then a technical question saying that if there are a lot of patients, and each patient will have some problems, how to store it. It was really easy…  to pass the phone interview. Don't worry about it.
questions: design the structure to store the patient's information

details: I applied online through epic's career websites.At first, I had the phone interview which went pretty well.Secondly, I had the online assessment test which has 2 sections, 1) learning new programming language 2) online coding1st section went ok but I messed up in the online coding section.
questions: How do you see yourself after next five years?

details: Very disappointed.....I will just share my on site interview experience. The procedure to reach the on site interview is similar to what other people have mentioned. I was interviewed for software Developer position at Madison last week. Immediately after one day, I got a phone call where my recruiter said that they were moving forward with other candidates. I am still confused what actually went wrong from my side.There were…  two dinners with Epic developer as hosts during this process. The hosts were really nice persons. There were couple of other candidates along with me interviewing for same position. In whole group, I was the only non-American. Most of the time they were talking about mostly American things- the sports, the lifestyle, etc. I hardly understood what they were talking. Most of the time, I was just putting fake smile on my face. I just request to the future hosts - please talk about something which everyone in the group can understand. My another bad luck - I had never gone to such a restaurant before. I guessed and ordered the food. I couldn't eat even half of it. The host saw it and seemed very unhappy about it. I don't know if the discussions with dinner hosts count in the hiring decision.On the D-day, there were presentations about the tools Epic has developed. Also a lunch session with a developer. These discussions went really well. I asked few questions, they promptly answered. There were three main interviews.The technical presentation interview was very bad experience. The interviewer did not seem to be interested in the interview. Over the 45 minutes, he didn't even smile once. I was giving presentation about my favorite project and was very enthusiastic about it. But the interviewer wasn't just interested. He looked bit tensed since the beginning and carried the same expression throughout the interview. . He asked couple of simple questions - just for the sake of formality. I was thinking what should I do so that he would be happy about my interview. A request to Epic - if someone is not interested in conducting the interview, please don't force them.Even when the the second technical interview (case study) started, I was still thinking about the previous interview. I thought I was losing my opportunity, but I somehow recovered. This guy was a nice one, very friendly. We discussed about a problem and I had to write the code. This interview went fine. Actually towards the end he said that he was expecting a different approach to the code than mine, but overall I convinced him about my overall logic and procedure.The HR interview went really well. Jeff was very friendly. After general discussion (Madison city, the interview experience, desired compensation, etc.), he asked me where could Epic improve. I mentioned few things and he seemed very happy.Overall, all the people (except the first technical interviewer) were nice. For future candidates, I will just say - Apart from technical preparation, please also pray for luck to be on your side. If your interviewer is not interested in the interview, you can't just do anything.I was really interested in working at Epic. I am still not sure what exactly was the reason for my rejection.
questions: Technical Project presentation, Writing code for a simple case study

details: Had a phone interview initially which lasted for 20 mins. Most of the ques are on my resume and then an online assessment exam which will be proctored. The exam consists of new programming language and some programs will be asked which we have to code. Time limit is not there but they will check your time taken. Waiting for result.
questions: They asked to explain about any project on my resume which i am comfortable with.

details: First Round: A recruiter schedules a telephonic interview with one of the team members. Its a 30 minutes interview with focus on resume and work experience. I was given a scenario and had to say which data structure should be used and why. Some technical algorithm, data structure questions.Second Round: Coding AssessmentUnlike others I had a 2 section test. First section was technical learning which had a new language and…  20 questions based on it. Second section was programming where I had 4 questions. (Questions are given below)Before the test I had asked if there is a time limit and I was told no, but when I was doing my last question I got a pop up window saying, "you have last 15 minutes before this test ends". That was strange and surprising.I'm still waiting on the result of the test.
questions: 1) Form number triangleGiven 5 -3 7 8 output should be5 -3 7 82 4 156 19252) SMS problem3) A company wants to give its employees a valid phone number. Find all possible numbers given conditions; - no two numbers are consecutive ie 0232 is valid but 0223 is not - if there is a 4 in the number then the first digit should also be 4 - there are 3 excluded numbers…  which shouldn't be in the result but the company has not yet decided which these numbers are going to be4) Snake sequence

details: phone interview, awaiting proctored testThe phone interview went exactly as others said, lasted about 30 minutes, about 15 of it was the interviewer talking about working there and benefits. Then I was asked to schedule an online proctored test, was told it would have math and coding (just like everyone else)
questions: why epic?why CS?where do you see yourself in the future?technical question: how would you design a robot that follows you around?

details: I received a mail from recruiter to apply for the job. I got a call in 2 days. It was a chat on my past project. How was it related to coding and all. Then I was given brief explanation about epic system and projects there.
questions: How did you hear about us?

details: There is an initial 45-minutes phone interview, I got a chance to talk about my projects. Then 3-4 hours assessment test. Latter onsite interview. The most difficult thing is assessment. Good luck for all.
questions: They are looking mainly looking for Wide programming skills and problem solving skills.

details: Initial 30-minute phone interview followed by "officially untimed" technical assessment. Assessment is done through a third party and (for me) involved two sections - one with 20 multiple-choice questions, and another with 4 coding problems ("write a method to do..."). Multiple-choice section involved answering questions about a made-up programming language - conceptually not very difficult, but because you can't ask any questions whatsoever except for technical ones, I had a…  hard time picking the "correct" answer. E.g., several of the questions asked for the output of some line of code, but without knowing the compiler's behaviour, several of the answer choices could have been correct.
questions: Why Epic?

details: I got the chance by apply online and change the position I apply from problem analysis to software development . They interview has 3 rounds, first is telephone interview; then is online assessment.
questions: questions are about data structure problems which you can answer in any language: check password; chess game

details: Phone interview is pretty much basic and easy to through. I was asked about couple of my previous projects and also about the programming languages i am good at.Assessment test is a bit difficult. Better to apply for the software developer position after gaining some real time experience.
questions: About the projects and qualifications

details: First a phone interview, secondly an online assessment, next an onsite interview and finally the job offer. The phone interview would take about 20-30 minutes. The results were informed within couple of days. In one or two days you will be get an email with information about online assessment. The online assessment would take 3-4 hours. The result would be inform within 1-2 weeks.
questions: 1) how did you get to know EPIC 2) Explain a project

details: Initial 30 minute phone interview in which they ask about your resume, experience, typical HR questions like "where do you see yourself in 5 years?". Generally a pretty casual talk.Shortly after that I was an online assessment. This had 4 sections (1 time limited, and 3 others not time limited but graded on time and accuracy): math (time limited), math (unlimited time), basic programming (unlimited), open-ended programming (unlimited). The math…  sections where basic algebra questions, the unlimited time one focusing more on reading comprehension with a couple of riddle questions. The basic programming section requires no previous coding experience, mostly just logic questions. The open-ended questions ask you to write some functions to solve a particular problem.After the online assessment was the on-site interview. For this they brought me in the day before the actual interview and a software developer took me out to dinner with a few other candidates. The dinner was casual and mostly an opportunity for us to ask about the company and the Madison area in general. The next day was the rest of the interview. This started with a talk from a software developer giving basic introduction to the company and the software they work on. Following that was a casual conversation with a software developer about what specifically they work on, life at Epic, and any questions we might have about the position. After that was a one on one case study with a software developer where they ask you to talk through a problem with them to a solution. They are looking at your thought process and problem solving skills here. This was followed with an informal lunch with a software developer and a tour of the campus. Then there was one on one interview with another developer in which you are asked to talk about a project. This is not a formal presentation, but meant to be more of a conversation. They will ask you questions about why you made certain choices and what you would do differently if you did it again, etc... Finally the day wrapped-up with an interview with the HR contact.
questions: Tell me about a software project you have worked on

details: Phone interview with a current employee, asking basic questions, such as why Epic. You will need to go through your resume and explain one or two items in detail. The employee will introduce you the focus of Epic and so on.
questions: Why Epic

details: Initially there was a phone screen with a software developer, he was an awesome guy. It was a casual talk, he went over my resume and asked a few questions over the design of one of my project. Then after a day, I got the link for an online assessment. There are many tricky questions, they look for the approach and nothing else. For the coding section, the editor will…  not lend any help and that is something that is not helpful. The 2 minute session get really tight, the numerical questions are gonna eat up much of time, and there are no options to choose from, I think if you answer at least 7 then you should be good. I'm waiting for their reply for the next steps.

Online application, Phone interview and then skills assessment. Waiting for the result. Skills assessment has four parts, math critical thinking, speed test, new programming language learning and programming skills. Programming skills part was relatively very tough, though most of them appeared from careercup.
questions: Explain the projects you've worked on earlier?

details: 1) Submitted application with transcript2) Got response in 2 days3) Phone Interview (Mostly behavioral questions and discussion about past work in resume)4) Must schedule online assessment in 3 business days.5) They email what date would be best to take exam. So, scheduled exam on that day.6) Exam had four sections: (a) 10 short questions that must be done in 2 mins (b) Maths (c) 4 programming questions (d) new programming…  language to learn and solve follow up questions. This exam takes around 2 to 3 hours. Faster is better for epic.I think, if you have good grades then they will sure take you to interview process. Online assessment is very demanding and only factor that tests your ability. So, before applying, you can prepare all questions from careercup as after application we don't get enough time to prepare. Though in phone interview they say online assessment is just to test coding skills on arrays and string and they won't test tough algorithm, we should focus on best solution/algorithm to solve coding problem. Try to solve all problems in optimal running time O(N) or less. That is all they test for quality.
questions: Why do you choose to be software developer?

details: I got a phone interview two weeks after the university job fair. Since I cannot make it on the certain day, I send them an email to them to see if I can have it another day. They are really nice and helpful. And give me the phone interview one week later.
questions: Why this company

details: About 30 min interview. They will call at exact time. You should be able to answer question regarding your resume. You will be asked to attend the skill test after 1-2 days. Its almost same what others wrote in this website.
questions: Tell me about the time that you have worked with clients and satisfied them?

details: I applied through their website and got contacted in two days. Then I was given a phone interview, which was easy, just to describe a project experience. After that, they emailed me the next day to schedule an online assessment. It took two to three hours to complete the whole assessment. Be sure to warm-up before the assessment by solving some critical thinking problems.
questions: Describe a project experience

details: First round phone interview, nice people to talk to. Then I got the second round, which is the online assessment. Four parts, maths, new language, 2 min questions, and coding. After 2-3 weeks, got the on-site invitation.
questions: Why epic?

details: First 15 minute informal phone call and online assessment, then on campus interview. Also a personality test online. Seems like online assessment is the primary thing that qualifies you for an on campus interview. I know I didn't get everything right, but I still got an offer, so don't sweat it. The on campus was great; everyone was nice, the campus was awesome.
questions: For the on campus, be ready to describe one project that you've done in depth.

details: The phone interview was quite easy. The hr is very nice and we just went over my resume. One day after phone interview, I received an OA link. I took the OA test after three days. All the questions in OA can be found in careercup. There are also 10 quick questions to be finished with 2 min. I only finished 7 of them.
questions: What is the most challenging project you did in school and how you fixed it?

details: Initially i received a mail from HR for a phone interview. Phone interview was simple. Interviewer was a developer at Epic and he just went through my Resume and asked my areas of interests. Also we discussed about the Projects that i had worked on earlier company. After 2 days i received a mail from the same HR that they want to move forward with the next steps. I was…  sent a Online Assessment link to complete. It usually consisted of 4 sections. 1)Speed Test 2)Critical thinking 3)New programming language 4)4 programming problems.I had given my assessment last week and been waiting to hear from them.
questions: Previous projects.

details: First, a phone interview. Then a 4-part online assessment consisting of a personality test, skills assessment, and programming assessment. This assessment is proctored by a third-party service, ProctorU. Last step is flying out for an on-campus interview in Madison, WI.
questions: Why Epic?

details: First there was a phone call.The interviewer asks you about the your experience,projects.Basic resume stuff. They follow up with a mail informing about the test. The whole scheduling process was very quick.Since the exam is through ProctorU we can choose any time. I am done with the exam and awaiting result for it.
questions: They asked basic math problems involving proportionality , guessing the next number in a series. The speed test tests your quick thinking. The programming questions were hard. Cant really tell the question because of the NDA. But it would be better if u go through matrix , arrays and data structures .

details: Phone Interview, Online Assessment. The phone interview was very easy. But the online technical assessment was way too tough. No fresher can crack this interview. The questions which are on reviews are not at all related to the real online exam. According to my experience only an experienced programmer with an experience of at least 7 years will only be able to crack this interview.
questions: They asked me to code 4 big programming concepts.

details: First a Phone Interview, followed by a technical assessment in a week. An onsite interview will be the last procedure. I finished the technical test last week and still waiting for the result.
questions: How did you know Epic? Why choose to be a software developer? Fully explain one of your projects on your resume. Any questions for interviewer?

details: They give me a phone interview after 1 week I submit my resume to their company. The phone interview is mainly about introduce your project. And after a few day they sent me the Online Assessment link. The questions has four parts: math, logic, programming and new language.The Online Questions are easy, but you must be very careful about your answers.
questions: Introduce one of your project

details: I got my friend referral. And 2 or 3 days later, I got an email from HR to set up a phone interview. As my first phone interview ever, it went pretty well.
questions: From when did you hear about Epic?
Why do you choose Software Developer?

details: First Round was a Telephonic Interview,resume based.Second Round was Online Test which consisted of 3 sections with last section of programming.Programming section was quite tough since I am not from Computer science background.
questions: First round- Resume briefing and challenges faced.Second round- was more of online test with objectives and programming assignments.

details: Onsite interview: Morning -- I make a presentation about my several projects, then had a skill interview with a programmer, they ask about algorithm;Had a lunch with people working in Epic; afternoon -- talk with HR, do personality test; have a great tour in epic campus. It's beautiful and huge. It's a private hold company. The CEO is a wonderful woman who start this company in 1970s.
questions: Talk about some project you did in your graduate study?

details: After applying online, I was contacted by human resource to set up a phone screen interview with a lead engineer. It was a casual conversation talking about my experience with programming and what projects I worked on previously. After being successful with the phone screen, I worked with HR to schedule a technical evaluation. The evaluation was done on my computer while being monitored via webcam. It consists of four…  sections and is around 3-4 hours long.
questions: Phone Screen: How to implement a taxi service application

details: I was interviewed for a posirion as a software developer. At first it was a casual phone interview not really on the technical side but more of why you want the job and what are your qualifications for it. The second part of the interview process includes the epic exam. I thought like most of the questions in the exam don't fit what a software developer really do need. It…  covered quite a big scope. I would suggest they give a material for the applicant to learn and then test them with it. Not everybody can prove themself in an online test it truly depends on too many factors such as time taken, emotion at the time and state of mind. I would suggest also testing then through a technical skype interview to really get a feel of the candidate rather than tagging them with a test score.
questions: why do you want this job?

details: Applied through university career fair, got a mail asking to schedule a phone interview. Interview was pretty normal. Everyone clears it. Then asked to take coding test online. Asked algorithms,Math,Reasoning and on some language. Questions were from carrier cup. Unlimited time is given but Speed and accuracy counts a lot when it comes to considering you for onsite call.Hope this helps
questions: Based on strings

details: quite comfortable interview, the interviewer is a Software Developer in that company. He's not really understand my area, for the information in my resume, he just asked a few simple questions. and he let me ask questions about his company, he told me some details about the position and their city.
questions: asked about the projects in my resume, just simple questions. Asked a question about database.

details: The job interview process was fairly standard for software developer positions. The first round is a phone interview to go over your resume in a little more detail. Then, you take their skills assessments online. After that, you are invited for an on-site interview, which consists of 3 parts. The first interview is simply a chance for a software developer to tell you about what they do at Epic. The…  second interview is a chance for you to talk in more detail about a specific project you have worked on. In the third interview, a software developer will ask you how you would design / implement a solution to a specific problem that might arise in the real world; it isn't about answering a textbook question or knowing specific algorithms / data structures.
questions: Describe a project you worked on.
How would you implement a solution to this problem that a doctor might face?

details: phone interview & and a online test. Do career cup's problem and you will be fine. I only took 2and half hours to finish the test, but after I turned it in, I found I got two bugs in it... so CHECK carefully before you turn it in since you can't really test it. Phone interview will ask a design question. Mine is given a robort and a maze, it…  has function that go forward, turn left/right. How can u walk the robort out of the maze.
questions: given a string, print all permutation of the string but uppercase letters and special chars don't move

details: a phone interview and an online assessement; In the phone interview, they just asked about my projects on the resume. and my programming experience. A week later, I got noticed that I need to take an online assessment. This assessment had 4 parts, first is 10 quick response questions, very easy, just be quick, you have 2 minutes limit; second is math questions, not hard, but need to be very…  careful; third is programming learning, they first teach you some basic rules about a new programming language and then test you each point they have shown you. I think this part is to test if you are a quick learner; the last part is 4 programming questions using the languages they have provided, for me, these questions are not very easy. It took a long time. Please prepare a calculator for the test. I forget to prepare one so it took longer to figure some questions. Please keep this in mind: being fast is important, but not as important as accuracy. You can find online assessment sample questions on the website to prepare for the assessment.
questions: In the phone interview, they just asked about my projects on the resume. and my programming experience. A week later, I got noticed that I need to take an online assessment. This assessment had 4 parts, first is 10 quick response questions, very easy, just be quick, you have 2 minutes limit; second is math questions, not hard, but need to be very careful; third is programming learning, they first…  teach you some basic rules about a new programming language and then test you each point they have shown you. I think this part is to test if you are a quick learner; the last part is 4 programming questions using the languages they have provided, for me, these questions are not very easy. It took a long time. Please prepare a calculator for the test. I forget to prepare one so it took longer to figure some questions. Please keep this in mind: being fast is important, but not as important as accuracy. You can find online assessment sample questions on the website to prepare for the assessment.

details: The process started with a telephonic call with one of Epic developer. He discussed my resume and basic stuff. He also talked for some time regarding my general understanding of Software Industry.Then I got a request to complete a ProctorU test. It had 4 segments as usual. I made some mistakes in Language section (I guess) but completed whole exam in less than 2 hours. I since most people fall in close range, time can be a factor. The programming questions were general(2 related to backtracking and 1 for recursive approach). About 2 weeks later, I was called in for onsite interview. Once you can get a onsite call, chance I guess are between 60% to 80% to convert into offer. There were 3 interviews(besides some presentations by company employees). 1st was project presentation round. details: Overview: 1 phone interview, 1 proctored online technical test, a few on-site interviews and Q&A sessions.Dropped my resume on their website in October 2014. From there, took a preliminary 30 minute interview with a software developer (not an HR guy) reviewing my past work and answering my questions about Epic.Proctored online test after that with a timed IQ test-style part, a brainteaser part, another to test how quick you can…  pick up a new programming language, and another that asks you to program a small function in a language of your choice.Didn't hear back for a while so I assumed I'd been turned down. News came in November 2014 that they wanted to fly me out for a day-long interview. They were very generous: they put us up in a Hilton in Madison, covered all cost of travel and food, and invited us to dinner with real Epic employees. (Tip: try the local specialties, like beer-battered cheese curds, and explore UW's campus.)Since the technical interview had already been taken care of online, the time spent on-site was mostly (I presume) used to gauge whether we meshed with the company culture and to show us what the workplace is like. They started with an overview of Epic's software suite (which was sorely needed--the website isn't very helpful for that), then had us break into small groups for Q&A with an employee.My rough patch was here. We were put one-on-one with a developer in a room with a whiteboard and asked to explain a project we'd worked on. I personally had only a very minor project to present, and my interviewer didn't seem too impressed when I finished before even half of my time had passed. I spent the rest of the session asking her questions about her job.Then we were taken to lunch in the cafeteria. Epic brings in gourmet chefs from Madison to do lunch and subsidizes the meals to about wholesale levels--big points scored there for me since I love food.The day ended with a tour of campus and Epic's peculiar workspaces. A few notable characteristics: (1) No cubicles. People are put in small groups in "real rooms". (2) Buildings have themes. We were shown the D&D/castle building, the NYC building, the Nordic building, and the newly-finished barn building. (3) Almost all software developers work on this campus to facilitate cooperation. (4) The Verona office is almost entirely off the grid, being powered by geothermal, solar, and wind energy.Received a call 2 weeks later saying they're extending an offer. As others have noted, a relocation stipend is available, as is prearranged housing. (Though you can choose to take that money and arrange your own housing.)

details: The application process was very streamlined and Epic HR are very good about maintaining communication. There are three stages: Phone Interview, Online Skills Assessment, and On-Site Interview.Phone Interview: The first part of the application process. Basically a ~30minute phone call with an Epic engineer talking about some of your previous experience, some code you've worked on and projects you've done, and interest in Epic.Skills Assessment: ~3 hour online skills assessment…  in which your mathematical and programming skills are tested. The test is proctored digitally so that you may only use what you already know, and any code written (any language) must be from your head and not from API or online code examples. The programming, which is by far the hardest section (math was very SAT-like, straightforward), has 4 open ended programming assignments that must be completed. Several of the questions had to do with string manipulation. Very little data structures knowledge was needed to complete the assessment, though recursion was useful.On-Site: Epic flies you out, dines you, and gives you a tour of the (incredible) campus. Most parts of the on-site interview are pretty stress-free, a lot of it involves speaking with various employees and engineers. Two "tests" of the interview include a 30 minute presentation of a previous project you've worked on to an engineer as well as answering some of his questions, as well as a short HR oriented talk.
