questions: No such question which I found was really tough, except the way they dealt for process. I was an applicant for developer position and never heard from them after personality test.

details: Got the mail from recruiter. Then took the Rembrandt profile test. Consists of analogies and basic mathematic questions. HR phone interview next.
questions: why Epic?

details: The interview process was very involved, more so than any other company I applied for. First was a phone interview, followed by a personality test with some simple math questions. Afterwords, I was invited for an on-site interview and assessment. It was nice to see Madison and I was made comfortable and well-fed, so in a way, it felt like a mini-vacation as I got to a small tour of…  the area. At the on-site tour, after given a preview of the environment, benefits, and product, I was given a series of assessment tests, mostly in logic, basic algebra, and because of the position I was applying for, a sort of programming test, as well as the interview before flying home. It had a weird mix of taking a standardized test and being in a liberal arts college.
questions: Was asked to give a 20 minute presentation with Q/A on my most challenging/rewarding programming project.

details: Applied online, then got an email from the hiring manager to arrange a phone interview. The phone interview was by a software engineer. Asked the questions based on my resume, such as describing a project you worked on before and your role in terms of coding. Also asked some routine questions, such as GPA of each degree. Emailed the hiring manager about the interview outcome after one week, then got…  rejection email after a couple of days.
questions: Describe a project you worked on before and your role in terms of coding

details: I received an email from them asking to book a phone interview with optional dates given. After the simple HR phone interview, had an Aptitude test which was pretty simple for a Master's student. They asked me to allot an exam center in my vicinity (like a public library with approval from a Procter). I had to go there and give a detailed Programming and Aptitude test.
questions: How many hours (max and average) of programming have you done in a week?

details: I had a phone inteview a couple of days ago. I had a discussion about my academic projects mentioned in my resume. Overall, it was an informative conversation about the work ethic and the job description of a software developer at Epic. After the interview, I am more interested in working there. I am still waiting for their decision.
I got a phone interview from them in May. It is HR oriented interview and completely not technical. I was asked why EPIC and what my career goal is.
questions: what is your career goal
why epic

details: I had a phone interrview with Epic last week. The question were mainly about education/experience background GRE/SAT score and few standard HR questions. I have a programming skills test next.I have been asked to take skills test in my local city. Any idea about the skills test questions type?
questions: What do you like about programming?

details: I first had a phone interview, then a skills assessment test. The exam is basically meant to test your programming skills. You are free to choose programming language of your choice or pseudo code. I feel this is the toughest part of the interview process. Once this is cleared, I was called for an on-site interview. It took 4-5 hours. They have spent lot of time in explaining their software…  and the position specific faqs.
questions: Would you like to be a team player or work alone?

details: I submitted my resume at University career fair and reported my GRE to the recruiter. In 3 days, I got an email scheduling a phone screen and a personality test for me. Now I have finished online test(which last 1 hour and it is boring) and waiting for the phone interview.
questions: no question .

details: Still in the interview process. I initially received an email via Monster.com. I applied on the website and received an email a few days later asking me my availability for a phone interview and asking me to take a Rembrandt personality profile. The phone interview was scheduled by the following day. The phone interview was simple--nothing really technical. I found it to be fairly informative about the company, though I…  did have some of my own questions prepared. The day after the phone interview I received an email to set up a skills test. The skills test, though, has not yet been scheduled.
questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
What is important to you when looking at a company?

details: I got this one from the campus career fair. Then one week later, I received the email for a personality test and phone interview. During the personality test, it more focus on whether you are creative person or a persist person. Then is the phone interview. No technical question. only Behaver question. I will take the test next week.
questions: How you know about EPIC
How much time could you travel?

details: I got in touch with Epic thorough my university. After submitting my resume, I first had a phone interview with a current employee which was followed by a skills assessment test involving Verbal math and 5 moderately difficult programming questions (Pseudo-code will do). Then I was invited to an on-site interview, which let us explore the beautiful campus in Verona and meet with Epic employees from different departments.
questions: How have you dealt with personal conflicts among team members in your projects before?

details: it went very well and they basically don't care about whether you have a lot of experience in programing. GPA will be the top 1 priority of the interview.
questions: What was your most challenging project you ever did.

details: They contacted me after seeing my resume on Monster.com. The first interview was by phone and it was pretty easy, simple background check to see if you will fit in the company and if you are willing to move to Verona, Wisconsin. After that they ask me to take an exam with a local proctor . The exam was long and they recommend you to finish it in two hours.…  I didn't.
questions: You could use any language in the test. There is a not disclose agreement, but I can say that they asked on the lines of data structures, optimization and the use of a calendar or like (day month hour) to solve a problem.

details: The HR guy asked me a couple of behavioral and background questions. Then asked to take an evaluation test online. After a couple days, they sent me an email to make an appointment to do a technical test. This test was an easy one, but make sure you finish it in a short time. I thought I did well, but got a rejection email after two weeks.
questions: What is your expected salary? Asked me to give a number.

details: They emailed me and told me I had good chance of getting a job if I were to post my resume on their website. About a week after I submitted my resume, I got letter from them saying that they have looked at my resume, they said they like it, but they have decided to go with other candidates
phone interview -> writing code on paper -> on site -> get the offer
questions: Are you familiar with VB?

details: they ask me to take a personality test online first. it is easy. then arrange a phone interview. They asked about GRE, GPA, some general questions and your experience on your resume. It take about half an hour.One month later, they arrange a skill test. It is programming test. 5 questions, all about string processing.
questions: print all well order numbers like (123,357...)

details: Still in the interview process. I initially received an email via Monster.com. I applied on the website and received an email a few days later asking me my availability for a phone interview and asking me to take a Rembrandt personality profile. The phone interview was scheduled by the following day. The phone interview was simple--nothing really technical. I found it to be fairly informative about the company, though I…  did have some of my own questions prepared. The day after the phone interview I received an email to set up a skills test. The skills test, though, has not yet been scheduled.

What is important to you when looking at a company?
